articles.headline: UPS Reaches Tentative Deal With Teamsters to Head Off Strike
articles.snippet: United Parcel Service faced a potential walkout by more than 325,000 union members after their five-year contract expires next week.
articles.abstract: United Parcel Service faced a potential walkout by more than 325,000 union members after their five-year contract expires next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Parcel Service announced Tuesday that it had reached a tentative deal on a five-year contract with the union representing more than 325,000 of its U.S. workers, a key step in averting a potential strike.

articles.headline: Education Dept. Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Harvard’s Legacy Admissions
articles.snippet: An inquiry into admissions preference for family of alumni and donors began after the Supreme Court’s decision last month limiting affirmative action.
articles.abstract: An inquiry into admissions preference for family of alumni and donors began after the Supreme Court’s decision last month limiting affirmative action.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Education Department has opened a civil rights investigation into Harvard University’s legacy admissions policy, inserting the federal government directly into a fierce national debate about wealth, privilege and race after the Supreme Court gutted the use of affirmative action in higher education.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine
articles.snippet: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
articles.abstract: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, gained ground in its most recent quarter against several of its lingering challenges, according to financial results released on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Hollywood Strike Leaves Influencers Sidelined and Confused
articles.snippet: Despite not being in the actors’ union, many content creators are passing up deals to promote films or TV shows because they don’t want to be barred from the guild or face online vitriol.
articles.abstract: Despite not being in the actors’ union, many content creators are passing up deals to promote films or TV shows because they don’t want to be barred from the guild or face online vitriol.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deanna Giulietti is not in the actors’ union, but she turned down $28,000 last week because of its strike.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Madison Malone Kircher

articles.headline: Credit Markets Are Creaking, Creating Economic Uncertainty
articles.snippet: Analysts warn that bankruptcies and defaults could jump as the world adjusts to higher interest rates.
articles.abstract: Analysts warn that bankruptcies and defaults could jump as the world adjusts to higher interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors and economists have become optimistic that the Federal Reserve might successfully slow inflation without plunging the economy into recession, but many are still eyeing a risk that threatens to derail the effort: a tower of dicey-looking corporate debt.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Judge Puts Hunter Biden’s Plea Deal on Hold, Questioning Its Details
articles.snippet: Judge Maryellen Noreika sent the two sides back to try to work out modifications that would address her legal and constitutional concerns and salvage the basic contours of the agreement.
articles.abstract: Judge Maryellen Noreika sent the two sides back to try to work out modifications that would address her legal and constitutional concerns and salvage the basic contours of the agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday put on hold a proposed plea deal between Hunter Biden and the Justice Department that would have settled tax and gun charges against the president’s son, stunning the courtroom and raising legal and constitutional questions about the agreement.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Michael S. Schmidt and Chris Cameron

articles.headline: Gov. Abbott’s Policing of Texas Border Pushes Limits of State Power
articles.snippet: The governor brought in razor wire, floating barriers and state troopers to deter unauthorized migration. The federal government mounted its first legal pushback this week.
articles.abstract: The governor brought in razor wire, floating barriers and state troopers to deter unauthorized migration. The federal government mounted its first legal pushback this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along Texas’ 1,200-mile-long border with Mexico, state troopers routinely arrest migrants for trespassing. Texas National Guard troops unspool razor wire along the banks of the Rio Grande. State game wardens patrol the river in fast-moving boats.

articles.headline: The Very Private Life of Melania Trump
articles.snippet: The former first lady has mostly retreated from public view — and steered clear of the campaign trail — while her husband fights to return to the White House and faces increasing legal peril.
articles.abstract: The former first lady has mostly retreated from public view — and steered clear of the campaign trail — while her husband fights to return to the White House and faces increasing legal peril.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since leaving the White House, Melania Trump’s world has gotten smaller.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Giuliani Concedes He Made False Statements About Georgia Election Workers
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still had “legal defenses” in a case brought by two election workers who said he had defamed them as he asserted that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani said he still had “legal defenses” in a case brought by two election workers who said he had defamed them as he asserted that the 2020 election was marred by fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani has conceded that while acting as a lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump, he made false statements by asserting that two Georgia election workers had mishandled ballots while counting votes in Atlanta during the 2020 election.

articles.headline: Fed Raises Rates After a Pause and Leaves Door Open to More
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials lifted borrowing costs by a quarter-point after pausing in June. Rates could rise more, but the central bank is not ready to commit.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials lifted borrowing costs by a quarter-point after pausing in June. Rates could rise more, but the central bank is not ready to commit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates to their highest level in 22 years and left the door open to further action as they continued their 16-month campaign to wrestle inflation lower by cooling the American economy.

articles.headline: G.M. and Other Automakers Will Build 30,000 Electric Vehicle Chargers
articles.snippet: The companies will jointly spend at least $1 billion to build a North American network in an effort to persuade more people to buy battery-powered cars and trucks.
articles.abstract: The companies will jointly spend at least $1 billion to build a North American network in an effort to persuade more people to buy battery-powered cars and trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven major automakers announced a plan on Wednesday to nearly double the number of fast chargers in the United States in an effort to address one of the main reasons that people hesitate to buy electric cars.
